abstract.p: Study finds that blacks who have heart attacks are less likely to receive proven treatments to prevent a recurrence, even when they are as inexpensive as aspirin or beta-blockers; finds smaller gaps in treatment of women versus men and low-income people versus higher ones (S)

block.p: A new study offers still more evidence that when it comes to health care, black and white patients do not always get equal treatment.

Circulation, the American Heart Association journal, is reporting today that blacks who have had heart attacks are less likely to receive proven treatments to prevent a recurrence, even when they are as inexpensive as aspirin or beta-blockers.
A new study offers still more evidence that when it comes to health care, black and white patients do not always get equal treatment.

Circulation, the American Heart Association journal, is reporting today that blacks who have had heart attacks are less likely to receive proven treatments to prevent a recurrence, even when they are as inexpensive as aspirin or beta-blockers.
The study, conducted at the Georgetown University, also found smaller gaps in the treatment of women versus men and low-income people versus higher ones.
Racial disparities in treatment have increasingly become an issue in medicine.
In this study, researchers evaluated what treatments patients were given when they entered hospitals and when they left. They looked at 169,079 Medicare beneficiaries hospitalized from 1994 to 1996.

For patients who have just had heart attacks, so-called clot-buster drugs and aspirin are known to improve the chances of survival. After discharge, aspirin and beta-blockers can prevent a recurrence.

The study found, for example, that in the hospital, about 63 percent of the white patients studied were given clot-busting drugs, but only about 56 percent of the black ones were. When the patients left, about 55 percent of the whites got prescriptions for beta-blockers, while about 50 percent of the blacks did.
While the researchers said they did not believe there was conscious discrimination, they said more study was needed to determine why the disparities occurred.
